title: How to Choose a Bread Maker

steps.headline: Estimate the amount of bread you will eat.
steps.description: Some bread makers can bake a 1-pound loaf, but the larger ones can make 2 pounds or more.

steps.headline: Decide where you will put the bread maker.
steps.description: This kitchen item tends to be big and boxy, so make sure you have enough counter space to keep it out. If not, consider where you will store it.

steps.headline: Find a bread maker that matches your kitchen.
steps.description: Most bread machines come in black or white to match appliances, but you can also find stainless steel and a few colorful shades.

steps.headline: Think about the shape of the bread.
steps.description: Most bread makers produce rectangular loaves, but some make round or square ones instead.

steps.headline: Check out the warranty.
steps.description: This allows you to enjoy the product for years since a good warranty offers free or cheap repairs should it break.

steps.headline: Choose a bread maker with a removable bread pan.
steps.description: This simplifies clean up. You can put a removable bread pan in the sink to wash, instead of wiping out the bread machine.

steps.headline: Decide whether you need the option of a delayed start.
steps.description: This is a nice feature if you want to add the ingredients before work, but want the bread to be fresh when you get home. However, you cannot use this feature with bread recipes that call for milk or eggs.

steps.headline: Choose a bread maker that will keep the finished product warm.
steps.description: This can be instead of or in addition to a delayed start option since it keeps the bread warm and fresh if you are not home to immediately enjoy it.

steps.headline: Browse bread makers that make specialty items.
steps.description: Some can mix pizza dough or cinnamon rolls. There are bread makers that also allow you to add fruit or nuts to make different types of bread.

steps.headline: Pick a product that can make gluten-free bread if necessary.
steps.description: Whether you are allergic to gluten, or are just trying to reduce your consumption of it, look for bread machines with a setting to make dough free of this ingredient.

steps.headline: Choose a bread maker with a viewing window.
steps.description: This allows you to check on the progress periodically.

steps.headline: Consider bread makers that tell you when to add additional ingredients.
steps.description: Certain models let you know when to toss in extras, such as fruit, nuts or chocolate chips.
